etymologies: mid 16th century (denoting an idle vagrant): probably from Latin rogare ‘beg, ask’, and related to obsolete slang roger ‘vagrant beggar’ (many such cant terms were introduced towards the middle of the 16th century)

examples.text: you are a rogue and an embezzler

definitions: a person whose behavior one disapproves of but who is nonetheless likable or attractive (often used as a playful term of reproof)
shortDefinitions: person whose behaviour one disapproves of but who is nonetheless likeable

definitions: an elephant or other large wild animal driven away or living apart from the herd and having savage or destructive tendencies
shortDefinitions: elephant or other large wild animal living apart from herd

definitions: a person or thing that behaves in an aberrant, faulty, or unpredictable way

examples.text: he hacked into data and ran rogue programs

shortDefinitions: person or thing that behaves in aberrant or unpredictable way

definitions: an inferior or defective specimen among many satisfactory ones, especially a seedling or plant deviating from the standard variety.
shortDefinitions: seedling or plant deviating from standard variety

definitions: remove inferior or defective plants or seedlings from (a crop)

examples.text: the sowing has to be rogued to remove aberrant seedlings

shortDefinitions: remove inferior or defective plants or seedlings from
